div1.p: Victory Over Disease Justifies Spanish War Cost of $1,148,000,000

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The World, February 26, 1911
div1.p:
VICTORY OVER DISEASE JUSTIFIES
SPANISH WAR COST OF $1,148,000,000.
--President Taft.

Executive's Declaration that
Medical Discoveries, Chiefly
by Army Physicians, Are
Greater Than in 200 Years of
European Colonization Is
Borne Out by Conquest of
Yellow Fever and Making
Tropical Possessions Healthy.

MEDICAL CORPS OFFICER
TELLS OF SANITARY WORK.

Discovery of Mosquito Infection
Ends Plague in United States,
Cuba and Philippines--Hook
Worm Identified and Remedy
Found--Thousands of Lives
Saved on Canal Zone.

p.hi:
“We have real ground for national
pride in the fact that England, France
and Germany--Germany not so much
so--and Holland have been engaged in
the colonial business in the tropics for a
hundred years, some of them two hun-
dred years, and yet it remained for
American physicians, and especially the
physicians in the army, to discover more
things in the ten years since the Spanish-
American war than were discovered in
the whole two centuries before that time;
and if nothing else justified the Spanish-
American war the discoveries of the
American physicians since that time--
what I may term the sequence of the war
--were ample to justify the expense of
that war ten times over.

div1.p:
“It is a real record of achievement of
a national character that every one who
understands it must dwell upon with
sincere pride.”--President Taft's message
to the Philadelphia Medical Club.

By Albert G. Love.
Captain [unclear] Medical Corps United
States Army; Assistant in Office
of Surgeon-General of Army.

Convincing proof of President
Taft's remarkable statement can
best be given by a brief summary of
some of the work accomplished by
the physicians to whom he paid his
tribute:

Yellow Fever--The primary ob-
ject of the war with Spain was the
liberation of Cuba from Spanish dom-
ination, but at the same time the
United States hoped to accomplish a
good deal in improving the sanitary
condition of the island. Yellow fever
had been continuously present in
Havana since 1762. There had been
numerous epidemics before 1762,
yellow fever being introduced there
as early as 1720. Between 1702 and
1878 yellow fever appeared in the
United States, according to Keating,
one hundred and twelve times, reach-
ing as far North as Nantucket Isl-
and, Mass., where 259 persons died
of it in 1763. Epidemics were fre-
quent in New York and Philadelphia.
In 1793 there were 4,041 deaths in
Philadelphia, which had a population
of 40,144. New York during earlier and
later invasions has had 3,454 deaths.
Bellevue Hospital was originally
planned as a yellow fever hospital.

The most frequent and destructive
epidemics were in the Southern States.
It is estimated that the epidemic of
1878 cost this country $100,000,000 in
addition to lives lost. In Memphis
there were 18,500 cases with 5,000
deaths. In New Orleans and in some
other Southern cities yellow fever was
epidemic the following years since
1878: 1879, 1880, 1883, 1889, 1897, 1898,
1899 and 1905. According to the best
figures obtainable there must have been
500,000 cases of yellow fever in the
United States from 1793 to 1900, with a
mortality of 100,000.
Mosquitoes Spread Yellow Jack.

Havana was the city from which the
United States was most frequently in-
fected. When the Americans took pos-
session in 1899, the work of sanitation
was at once started. Major (now Colo-
nel) Gorgas of the Medical Corps of the
Army was in charge. Cases soon began
to appear in the army and when immi-
grants began to come in in large num-
bers yellow fever there became preva-
lent. One-third of the officers on the
staff of Gen. Leonard Wood died of yel-
low fever. In the summer of 1900 the

div1.p:
Yellow Fever Commission of the United
States Army was organized, consisting
of the following medical officers of the
United States Army: Major Walter
Reed, Dr. James Carroll, Dr. Jesse W.
Lazear and Dr. Aristides Agramonte.
By a series of well planned and scien-
tifically conducted experiments this
commission demonstrated to the world
that yellow fever is transmitted from
one person to another only by a certain
species of mosquito, and cannot be
transmitted in any other way. Major
Gorgas at once began working along
the lines outlined by the commission:
First, the destruction of all mosqui-
toes, and especially mosquitoes in the
vicinity of yellow fever patients; sec-
ond, the protection of yellow fever
patients from the mosquitoes, and
third, the protection of non-immune
subjects from mosquitoes.

This work was started in February,
1901, and after September, 1901, no more
cases occurred in Havana or Cuba until
1905, when it was again banished by the
army physicians during the second in-
tervention. Only once since 1899 has yel-
low fever gained a foothold in the United
States, in 1905, when it was wiped out
of New Orleans and vicinity by Dr.
White of the Public Health and Marine
Hospital Service.
Discovery of Hook-Worm.

Hook-Worm.--Capt. (now Major) Bai-
ley K. Ashford, Medical Corps, U. S.
Army, demonstrated to the world that
the tropical anaemia so prevalent in
Porto Rico was caused by a small in-
testinal worm known as the hook-worm.
In 1899 Dr. Ashford established a hos-
pital there for hurricane victims. Fully
three-fourths were suffering from an-
aemia, due to hook-worm. A commis-
sion was appointed consisting of Dr.
Ashford, Dr. W. W. King, U. S. Pub-
lic Health and Marine Hospital Service,
and Dr. Pedro Gutierrez, health officer
at Bayamon. About 300,000 cases were
treated, of whom over 40 per cent. were
entirely cured and the remainder re-
lieved. The average death-rate in the
island for the first five years of the
work was 33.48 per 1,000, and for the last
five years 23.33 per 1,000.

Sanitation of Panama Canal.--The
French failed to complete the Panama
Canal because of the very high mortality
among employees from yellow fever and
malaria. They could not live or work
there. When the Americans went there
Col. Gorgas went with them, and the
following extract from an article by Dr.
William Osler relates the result:
Dr. Osler on Panama Sanitation.

“The digging of the Panama Canal
was acknowledged to be a question of
the health of the workers. For four cen-
turies the Isthmus had been a white
man's grave, and at one time during
French control of the Canal the mor-
tality reached 170 per 1,000.

“Month by month I get the reports,
which form by far the most interesting
sanitary reading of the present day. Of
more than 54,000 employees (about 13,000
of whom are white) the death rate per
1,000 for March was 8.91, a lower per-
centage, I believe, than in any city in
the United Kingdom and very much
lower than in any city in the United
States.”

The Work of Sanitation During the
Second Intervention in Cuba.--When the
American army was withdrawn from
Cuba May 20, 1902, together with the
sanitary chiefs and the medical officers
of the army, a relapse of sanitary work
throughout the island occurred. Havana
became infected in 1905 with yellow
fever from New Orleans. In a short
time yellow fever was widespread
throughout the island and remained so
until the second intervention. Then,
under the able direction of Major (now
Colonel) Kean of the Army Medical
Corps, sanitary matters were again
regulated and yellow fever once more
put to flight. Major Kean then recog-
nized that to prevent such a recurrence
there must be a national health depart-
ment. He prepared the sanitary laws
of Cuba now in force, and as long as
they are observed Cuba can never re-
lapse into its former deplorable sani-
tary condition.

Small-Pox--By compulsory vaccina-
tion of the inhabitants of Porto Rico,
Cuba and the Philippines by the army
medical officers small-pox has been prac-
tically wiped out. Not a single death
has occurred from small-pox in Porto
Rico since the civil government was es-
tablished; the occurrence is much less
frequent in Cuba than in the United
States, and the disease occurs infre-
quently among the Filipinos.

President Taft, as Governor of the
Philippines, established a Department
of Public Health on a scale to cope
successfully with the devasting epi-
demics of plague and cholera which had
marked the history of those islands.
He also established the laboratories of
the Bureau of Science at Manila, which
have assisted greatly in the study of
tropical diseases. He also established
a leper colony at Culion which promises
to be the means of stamping out this
terrible disease. The civil hospital in
Manila is another monument to Gov.
Taft.

“SPANISH WAR AIDED
MEDICAL RESEARCH.”

“Brought New Problems Which
Army Doctors Solved,”
Says Dr. Siglar.

“When President Taft told of discov-
eries concerning tropical diseases made
by American physicians since the Span-
ish war he placed his finger on a signifi-
cant fact,” said Dr. Henry Burr Siglar,
No. 24 State street, Manhattan, yester-
day.

“No concentrated thought had been
paid to many mysterious diseases of the
tropics. The Spanish war changed all
this. Yellow fever in Cuba, the hook
worm in Porto Rico, leprosy in the Phil-
ippines and other dread complaints be-
came our heritage. Immediately we
had taken Cuba we were face to face
with the problem of cleansing it. Not
only was sanitation enforced, but the
army physicians gave battle to the
ancient plague of yellow fever in its own
lair, and the theory that the fever
originated from the bite of a certain
kind of mosquito was confirmed. Once
having been settled for all time, the
remedy for the epidemics that had swept
the island was comparatively plain.

“Dr. Walter Reed, a surgeon in the
United States Army, and others demon-
strated the theory at the risk of their
lives. Dr. Reed built a little, ill-venti-
lated frame house in Cuba near the vil-
lage of Quemados, used bed clothing
from Havana hospitals where yellow
fever patients had died, and his five
companions, enlisted men, wore night-
clothes in which patients had expired.
Everything was done to make yellow
fever probable, with one exception--wire
screens were put in the windows, through
which no mosquitoes could enter. None
of these heroes contracted fever. Then
another house was built in two sections.
One was screened, the other was not.
Seven men lived in each section for
seven weeks. Of tthose in the screened
section none became ill, but five of those
in the unscreened section came down
with the disease. It was a complete
demonstration.

“Upon our shoulders had been placed
a burden that older people had tired of
and had borne indifferently. The army
medical men did their best. Rich men
saw the necessity of great and well en-
dowed laboratories where students free
from the cares of making a living could
fight the battle against disease success-
fully. Such institutions as the Rocke-
feller Institute followed. Not only our
own diseases were taken up, but also
those of our colonies. The most success-
ful feat there has been the discovery
of the cerebro-spinal meningitis serum,
which has reduced the mortality from
per cent. in this disease.”
